repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Second National Low-Income
            Housing Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Second National HousingProject in
            Ecuador. The project had the following objectives: (i)
            increasing the production of low-income housing; (ii)
            adoption by Ecuadorian Housing Bank (BEV) of interest rate
            policies and a new mortgage instrument designed to improve
            resource mobilization and allocation in the housing sector;
            (iii) further streamlining and strengthening of the
            financial, administrative and productive efficiency of BEV/
            National Housing Board (JNV) within a continued process of
            rationalization of the Government's public housing
            investment program; (iv) better targeting of BEV/JNV
            production to make it more responsive to the needs of
            low-income beneficiaries; and (v) fostering greater
            participation of private contractors/developers in the
            production of low-income housing. The results show that
            while the physical goals were surpassed, the institutional
            goals and more far-reaching efforts to establish an entity
            with a largely self-sustaining system were not very
            successful. Overall, the Borrower remained in compliance
            with loan covenants. The following are some of the key
            lessons learned from this project: 1) Use of a specialized
            public-sector entity such as BEV to capture funds in the
            market for long-term mortgage lending on a largely
            commercial basis and for low-income groups is not feasible;
            2) Trying to satisfy housing sector demand for low-income
            groups through public-sector housing construction programs
            is not sustainable; 3) To reach lower-income groups and
            encourage greater activity in the sector, a greater emphasis
            on demand analysis and the lowering of norms and standards
            is required.

repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Second National Low-Income
            Housing Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second National Low Income Housing
            Project seeks to finance a share of BEV's 1988-1993
            investment program which is to be implemented throughout
            Ecuador through BEV, JNV and private developers.  It aims to
            support adoption of new financial policies and instruments
            to improve resource mobilization and allocation and housing
            affordability in the sector and promote institutional
            reforms within BEV and JNV to make them more efficient.  The
            loan intends to finance (i) approximately 12,000 serviced
            lots with or without dwelling units, (ii) about 15,000 home
            improvement credits (iii) vehicles and equipment for project
            implementation and (iv) technical assistance for project agencies.

docna.cdata!: Ecuador - Second National Low-Income Housing Project
